name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

key_work.title: Drive Me to the Moon
key_work.credit_line:
Key art, concept art & stills from Drive Me To The Moon

Olivia Haines, Australia, 2019

Courtesy Olivia Haines
key_work.brief_description:
From Mad Max to Grand Theft Auto, cars on-screen are almost universally symbols of aggressive masculinity, competition and violence. But what if you weren’t going fast? What if you were going on a date instead?

In Drive Me to the Moon (2019), a car is not a speed machine, a weapon, or compensating for something – it’s your date night vehicle. The player takes the wheel not to race against the clock, but to cruise around a gorgeous, dollhouse world, enjoying the scenery with a cutie by her side.

Drive Me to the Moon is an early example of Haines’ now-established signature style: pastel tones, a small and beautifully rendered world, and a pro-social underpinning, reflecting Haines’ profound respect for feminine sociality.

constellations_primary.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_primary.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

start.title: Carol
start.creator_credit: Todd Haynes, Sandy Powell, Christine Vachon, Elizabeth Karlsen, Stephen Woolley, Tessa Ross, Film4 Productions, Killer Films, Number 9 Films, Judy Becker, Phyllis Nagy and Erik Werlin
start.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2015
start.brief_description: In 1950s New York, a department-store clerk who dreams of a better life falls for an older, married woman.

constellations_other.name: From gallery to screen
constellations_other.description: Explore how famous films, videogames and music videos have taken their cue from the art of the past.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

end.title: WandaVision
end.creator_credit: Mayes C. Rubeo, Chuck Hayward, Marvel Studios and Mark Worthington
end.brief_description: Wanda Maximoff and Vision—two super-powered beings living idealized suburban lives—begin to suspect that everything is not as it seems.

constellations_other.name: Superhero special effects
constellations_other.description: VFX talent isn't limited to just one studio that makes superhero blockbusters.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

constellations_other.name: Mayes C Rubeo
constellations_other.description: Emmy-award winning and Oscar-nominated costume designer Mayes C Rubeo has worked on some of Hollywood's biggest blockbusters, designing costumes for characters and creatures across time, space and everything in between.

links.description: Inspired by 1950s female photographers, the cinematography in Carol positions audiences as observers to highlight the societal constraints on women during the period. WandaVision similarly emulates 1950s and 1960s female-centred sitcoms, revealing the societal expectation of women to solely be housewives.

start.title: Heavenly creatures
start.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Jim Booth and Wingnut Films
start.brief_description: Set in the 1950’s in New Zealand, this film is based on a true story that shocked the nation at the time. New arrival Juliet Hulme (Kate Winslet) quickly befriends the quiet Pauline Parker (Melanie Lynskey) at their conservative school in Christchurch. Although their backgrounds are very different, the two girls are both creative and intelligent writers, and form a close friendship which gradually becomes more and more obsessive. Together, they create a fantasy world peopled by characters who become very real for both of them. Their parents are increasingly disturbed by the obsessive nature of their relationship, and take steps to separate them. This leads to the girls plotting a horrendous crime to ensure they remain together.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

end.title: Carol
end.creator_credit: Todd Haynes, Sandy Powell, Christine Vachon, Elizabeth Karlsen, Stephen Woolley, Tessa Ross, Film4 Productions, Killer Films, Number 9 Films, Judy Becker, Phyllis Nagy and Erik Werlin
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2015
end.brief_description: In 1950s New York, a department-store clerk who dreams of a better life falls for an older, married woman.

constellations_other.name: From gallery to screen
constellations_other.description: Explore how famous films, videogames and music videos have taken their cue from the art of the past.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

links.description: Heavenly Creatures and Carol are both set in the 1950s, seeking to accurately recreate the period across set design, costuming and props, while also revealing the prevalence of homophobia during the period.

start.title: But I'm a Cheerleader
start.creator_credit: Andrea Sperling, Leanna Creel, Lionsgate and The Kushner-Locke Company
start.brief_description: Megan is an all-American girl. A cheerleader. She has a boyfriend. But Megan doesn’t like kissing her boyfriend very much. And she’s pretty touchy with her cheerleader friends. Her conservative parents worry that she must be a lesbian and send her off to “sexual redirection” school, where she must, with other lesbians and gays learn how to be straight.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

constellations_other.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_other.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

end.title: Heavenly creatures
end.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Jim Booth and Wingnut Films
end.brief_description: Set in the 1950’s in New Zealand, this film is based on a true story that shocked the nation at the time. New arrival Juliet Hulme (Kate Winslet) quickly befriends the quiet Pauline Parker (Melanie Lynskey) at their conservative school in Christchurch. Although their backgrounds are very different, the two girls are both creative and intelligent writers, and form a close friendship which gradually becomes more and more obsessive. Together, they create a fantasy world peopled by characters who become very real for both of them. Their parents are increasingly disturbed by the obsessive nature of their relationship, and take steps to separate them. This leads to the girls plotting a horrendous crime to ensure they remain together.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

links.description: Before starring in But I’m A Cheerleader, Melanie Lewinsky made her acting debut in Heavenly Creatures: a period film that is similarly centred on a queer relationship.

start.title: Barbie
start.creator_credit: Greta Gerwig, Jacqueline Durran, Nick Houy, David Heyman, Margot Robbie, Robbie Brenner, Tom Ackerley, Heyday Films, LuckyChap Entertainment, Mattel, NB/GG Pictures, Sarah Greenwood and Noah Baumbach
start.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2023
start.brief_description: Barbie and Ken are having the time of their lives in the colorful and seemingly perfect world of Barbie Land. However, when they get a chance to go to the real world, they soon discover the joys and perils of living among humans.

constellations_other.name: Pink subversions
constellations_other.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

end.title: But I'm a Cheerleader
end.creator_credit: Andrea Sperling, Leanna Creel, Lionsgate and The Kushner-Locke Company
end.brief_description: Megan is an all-American girl. A cheerleader. She has a boyfriend. But Megan doesn’t like kissing her boyfriend very much. And she’s pretty touchy with her cheerleader friends. Her conservative parents worry that she must be a lesbian and send her off to “sexual redirection” school, where she must, with other lesbians and gays learn how to be straight.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

constellations_other.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_other.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

links.description: Similar to Barbie, the creators of But I’m A Cheerleader also looked to the original 1962 Barbie Dreamhouse as a source of inspiration for the True Directions set, highlighting how heteronormative perceptions of gender roles are artificial.

start.title: Barbie
start.creator_credit: Greta Gerwig, Jacqueline Durran, Nick Houy, David Heyman, Margot Robbie, Robbie Brenner, Tom Ackerley, Heyday Films, LuckyChap Entertainment, Mattel, NB/GG Pictures, Sarah Greenwood and Noah Baumbach
start.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2023
start.brief_description: Barbie and Ken are having the time of their lives in the colorful and seemingly perfect world of Barbie Land. However, when they get a chance to go to the real world, they soon discover the joys and perils of living among humans.

constellations_other.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

end.title: All about my mother = Todo sobre mi madre [Widescreen]
end.creator_credit: Pedro Almodovar, Esther Garcia, El Deseo S. A., France 2 Cinema and Renn Productions
end.brief_description: Cecilia Roth plays Manuela, a single working mother whose life takes a tragic twist when her son is killed in a road accident after a performance of “A Streetcar Named Desire”. Manuela decides to return to Barcelona and confront her son’s missing father, hoping that by correcting the mistakes in her past she can find some hope of alleviating the anguish and despair of grief. In Barcelona Manuela finds herself integrated into a new family consisting of transvestite prostitute Agrado (Antonia San Juan), a HIV positive Catholic nun (Penelope Cruz), and the great actress Huma Roja (Marisa Paredes) whose performance as Blanche in “Streetcar” was so beloved by Manuela’s son. Almodovar’s earlier films were absurdist comedies about the sexual and cultural values of a Spain emerging from under Franco’s fascist rule. “All About My Mother” retains his comic surrealism, and the characters still inhabit a world where traditional gender and sexual differences are rendered meaningless, but the film is also a homage to great Hollywood melodrama and in particular the great female legends of the stage and screen. Manuela’s escape from grief occurs only when she can reclaim motherhood, but it is an ideal of motherhood and family not rooted in biology but in friendship and the acceptance of difference. This film says the world is harsh, ugly and unfair but that through the bonds humans make with one another it can also be warm, generous and beautiful. This loving tribute to women (in all their aspects) contains splendid cinematography by Affonso Beatto. (Awards: Winner of the Academy Award and Golden Globe for Best Foreign Language Film. Winner of Best Director Award at the Cannes Film Festival) In Spanish with English subtitles.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

links.description: Like Barbie, All About My Mother takes its cue from the 1950s film All About Eve, as well as features distinctive modernist furnishings, to create a rich world that celebrates women as mothers, friends and performers.

start.title: Drive Me to the Moon
start.credit_line:
Key art, concept art & stills from Drive Me To The Moon

Olivia Haines, Australia, 2019

Courtesy Olivia Haines
start.brief_description:
From Mad Max to Grand Theft Auto, cars on-screen are almost universally symbols of aggressive masculinity, competition and violence. But what if you weren’t going fast? What if you were going on a date instead?

In Drive Me to the Moon (2019), a car is not a speed machine, a weapon, or compensating for something – it’s your date night vehicle. The player takes the wheel not to race against the clock, but to cruise around a gorgeous, dollhouse world, enjoying the scenery with a cutie by her side.

Drive Me to the Moon is an early example of Haines’ now-established signature style: pastel tones, a small and beautifully rendered world, and a pro-social underpinning, reflecting Haines’ profound respect for feminine sociality.

constellations_other.name: Pink subversions
constellations_other.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

links.description: Drive Me To The Moon combines pastel pink aesthetics with 1950s-inspired buildings and signage, creating a gentle world for a lesbian date. Barbie was similarly inspired by 1950s soundstage musicals and modernist design in building the idealised feminine utopia Barbieland.
